pageProps.contentHtml:
density argument

Suppose dμ\diff\mudμ is a Borel probability measure on the unit circle in the complex plane such that

lim⁡n→∞∫{∣z∣=1}zn dμ(z)=0.\lim_{n\to\infty} \int_{\set{\abs{z}=1}} z^n \,\diff\mu\p{z} = 0.n→∞lim​∫{∣z∣=1}​zndμ(z)=0.

For f∈L1(dμ)f \in L^1\p{\diff\mu}f∈L1(dμ), show that

lim⁡n→∞∫{∣z∣=1}znf(z) dμ(z)=0.\lim_{n\to\infty} \int_{\set{\abs{z}=1}} z^nf\p{z} \,\diff\mu\p{z} = 0.n→∞lim​∫{∣z∣=1}​znf(z)dμ(z)=0.
Solution.

Notice that if p=a0+⋯+amzmp = a_0 + \cdots + a_mz^mp=a0​+⋯+am​zm is a polynomial, then

lim⁡n→∞∫znp(z) dμ(z)=lim⁡n→∞∑k=0mak∫zk+n dμ(z)=0.\lim_{n\to\infty} \int z^n p\p{z} \,\diff\mu\p{z} = \lim_{n\to\infty} \sum_{k=0}^m a_k \int z^{k+n} \,\diff\mu\p{z} = 0.n→∞lim​∫znp(z)dμ(z)=n→∞lim​k=0∑m​ak​∫zk+ndμ(z)=0.

To generalize to f∈L1(S1)f \in L^1\p{S^1}f∈L1(S1), first observe that the unit circle S1S^1S1 is compact, so we may apply Stone-Weierstrass. Let A={∑k=0nakzk∣n∈N,ak∈C}A = \set{\sum_{k=0}^n a_kz^k \mid n \in \N, a_k \in \C}A={∑k=0n​ak​zk∣n∈N,ak​∈C}. It's clear that AAA is closed under scaling by C\CC, addition, and multiplication, so AAA is an algebra. 1∈A1 \in A1∈A, so AAA vanishes nowhere. Finally, z∈Az \in Az∈A, so AAA separates points. Thus, AAA is dense in C(S1)C\p{S^1}C(S1) with respect to the uniform norm, hence with respect to the L1L^1L1 norm. Moreover, C(S1)C\p{S^1}C(S1) is dense in L1(dμ)L^1\p{\diff\mu}L1(dμ), so given ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0 and f∈L1(dμ)f \in L^1\p{\diff\mu}f∈L1(dμ), there exists p=a0+⋯+amzmp = a_0 + \cdots + a_mz^mp=a0​+⋯+am​zm such that ∥f−p∥L1<ε\norm{f - p}_{L^1} < \epsilon∥f−p∥L1​<ε. Thus, if nnn is large enough, then ∣∫znp∣<ε\abs{\int z^np} < \epsilon∣∣​∫znp∣∣​<ε and so

∣∫znf(z) dμ(z)∣≤∣∫znp(z) dμ(z)∣+∫∣zn(f(z)−p(z))∣ dμ(z)≤ε+∫∣f(z)−p(z)∣ dμ(z)(we’re integrating over ∣z∣=1)≤2ε.\begin{aligned} \abs{\int z^nf\p{z} \,\diff\mu\p{z}} &\leq \abs{\int z^np\p{z} \,\diff\mu\p{z}} + \int \abs{z^n\p{f\p{z} - p\p{z}}} \,\diff\mu\p{z} \\ &\leq \epsilon + \int \abs{f\p{z} - p\p{z}} \,\diff\mu\p{z} && (\text{we're integrating over } \abs{z} = 1) \\ &\leq 2\epsilon. \end{aligned}∣∣​∫znf(z)dμ(z)∣∣​​≤∣∣​∫znp(z)dμ(z)∣∣​+∫∣zn(f(z)−p(z))∣dμ(z)≤ε+∫∣f(z)−p(z)∣dμ(z)≤2ε.​​(we’re integrating over ∣z∣=1)​

Sending ε→0\epsilon \to 0ε→0, we get the claim.
